urn:contentItem:67T8-B3B1-JCS1-61NC-00000-00TuSimple Holdings Inc at JPMorgan Industrials Conference - Final2023-03-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:56ZLexisNexis031623a15518059.759TuSimple Holdings Inc at JPMorgan Industrials Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Cheng Lu

TuSimple Holdings Inc. - President, CEO & Director

Conference Call Participants

* Brian Patrick Ossenbeck

JPMorgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Senior Equity Analyst

Presentation

BRIAN PATRICK OSSENBECK, SENIOR EQUITY ANALYST, JPMORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. We are back here on Day 3 of the transports track for JPMorgan Industrials Conference. Brian Ossenbeck, I cover the group. And we are moving into the autonomous on the freight tech side of things with TuSimple. So we have Cheng Lu, who is back as the CEO of the company. There's clearly been quite a lot going on in the freight tech space, but with autonomous trucking in general. So very happy to have him today, give us an update, probably go through like 10 or 15 minutes of the presentation. The slides are up here. If you have questions in the room, raise your hand, we'll get you a mic. And then we'll come back for some Q&A.

So Cheng, thank you very much for being here. I'll kick it over to you.

CHENG LU, PRESIDENT, CEO & DIRECTOR, TUSIMPLE HOLDINGS INC.: Great. Brian, thanks for having me. Good morning, everyone. So I'll just get started with some presentation and -- sorry, when -- it's a short presentation. A quick overview of TuSimple. We'll talk about some of the investment highlights. And lastly, looking forward in terms of 2023, what to expect in terms of our financial forecast.

This overview, our mission is to enable the most safe, fuel-efficient and low-cost freight capacity. And we're doing so by developing the best Level 4 self-driving technology by integrating that with hardware and with our network-based go-to-market strategy, the Autonomous Freight Network.

At a quick glance, today, we're about 1,100 employees globally. We have about 60 active trucks, doing self-driving on the road. We're delivering freight out of 3 terminals. 80% of our employees are R&D-focused engineers. One of the cool things I want to talk about is our launch of our proprietary autonomous domain controllers or the central compute. In a way, this allows us to be a next-generation Mobileye.

We do have the largest homegrown patent portfolio globally for self-driving truck application. Based on third-party analysis, we can say that this portfolio is also the most innovative. And I think that creates a lot of value for TuSimple. And earlier this year, we reached 10 million miles of road miles. And it's nice because it is a testament to the safety culture as well as our productivity.

So before I get into investment highlights, I do want to say the obvious, 2022 was a difficult year for us. I think in a way, we are a victim of our own success. We tried to do too many things too fast. I would say the prior leadership lacked experience or judgment, created things that unfortunately were self-inflicted harm. And on top of that, you add the geopolitical tension and a match became a forest fire.

Over the last several months, the team really has rallied. We've stabilized the management team. There's been no turnover on that side. We improved corporate governance. We reduced cost, streamlined operations while having a clear road map in terms of how we go forward. And of course, we do still have a lot of work remaining and some unresolved items. But I'm here today because I do feel like this is a good time for a relaunch. We're ready for a relaunch. And I'm excited of what's coming.

And so let me kind of share a few highlights why I think that's the case. So in terms of what gets me excited about TuSimple and also one of the reasons why I came back is, look, fundamentally, the investment thesis for self-driving trucks haven't changed. It's still a massive market and the supply/demand dynamics haven't -- it's only gotten worse. And so the need for freight capacity continues to persist.

Second is TuSimple, our track record speaks for ourself. We are, I will say, one of the few companies that have constantly demonstrated where hit the milestones that we set out to achieve, and that's important in this industry, right? It is one that is based on credibility and, of course, that provides a good foundation for us to move forward.

Third is we have enhanced our corporate governance and some of the regulatory overhang. And so kind of pleased to make the progress there.

Number four, everyone talks about commercialization. We do believe we'll be first to commercially launch a self-driving lane. And I'll share about why we think that's the case. What's the framework. And again, given what we've proved in the past, why -- you should trust us that we can achieve these milestones.

Number five is -- this is new. Since last year, we announced a partnership with NVIDIA to co-develop a domain controller. And this is not something where we use all their existing chips and systems, but really ground up central computer. And this is a big part of capturing this wave in automotive where edge computing on the sensor level where you're having hundreds of different ECUs are all moving back -- moving towards a centralized supercomputer because they need to process a lot of data and actually is more cheaper and more efficient.

And lastly is we are one holding company. Over the last several years, we became 2 distinct businesses. There are some shared resources. But between our U.S. and China operations, we're doing different things, different technology road maps, but there's value here to be created to shareholders, given kind of what we can do with 2 distinct businesses. And I think today, we're trading below our cash value. I do believe that where we are in technology, where we are in terms of what we developed so far and the road map we have going forward, I do think there's hopefully more value we can unlock for shareholders.

So I'll quickly run through some of the highlights on each of these investment thesis. I mean it goes without saying that this is just North America freight market, 3 million Class A trucks, 80% -- or 70% of all freight moves on trucks. And the nice thing is they move, especially on long haul, across what basically 5 or 6 major interstate highways. So really a loss of density and getting a few highways automated can create a very viable, very large business. And this is different in robotaxi, right? Because you had really go from city to city, and you're covering a much denser area, if you want to provide a service at each city. The supply -- I mean, ultimately, for freight industry, it's a commoditized business. It's really just about supply and demand, right?

The supply of truck drivers continue to get smaller and smaller. The demand, because of e-commerce, because of -- we want things sooner, faster, continues to increase. And the cost of safety have continued to go up. The big thing for the freight industry is these nuclear verdicts. And that's something that I think is -- it is my understanding is not getting that much better. And so this is all the things that self-driving can, of course, help. And this is why our fundamental mission, we're not here to build a self-driving truck. We're here to automate freight lanes one lane at a time and add capacity that is safe, reliable and low cost to this ecosystem.

One of the really, I think, standout things for TuSimple is we are the only player in the self-driving truck industry to have done full self-driving runs. These are 80-mile runs from Tucson to Phoenix. I think there's been a lot of talk about difference between trucking and robotaxis. Two things to point out here. One is to commercialize, everybody has to go through this phase of being able to drive without a human driver. And the reason is because you have to prove that you're feature complete, right, the truck can drive on this operational design domain without human assistance.

And second is you had to improve the redundancy of the system. Just having -- driving on a very sort of -- where everything is perfect is one thing, but the reality is we have to basically design and build the system and test the system for when everything isn't perfect. And so that level redundancy is very important. And I would argue that one of the -- probably the biggest challenges for trucking -- actually trucking is quite harder to do full self-driving than robotaxis for one reason, and that's because you can't just stop the truck in the middle of a highway, right?

So if you're in a city, in San Francisco and it's -- there's a malfunction, a system error, worse comes to worst, you can kind of stop in the middle of the road. Now you (expletive) off the people behind you, but it's relatively safe. For a truck, you cannot stop when you're going 65 miles an hour. You have to safely pull over to the side or the shoulder. And so that alone, you can imagine the level of reliability and redundancy that's required, the fail operational. And so that's something that we have demonstrated safely. And that's the foundation for -- how we move forward from there.

In terms of corporate governance, now last year, there's -- currently still, of course, we had quite a bit of turnover and issues on this side. We built a new Board starting November that I would -- I believe is better suited to guide the company through some of the issues and strategic priorities that we have. So Mike and Tyler, both have strong regulatory experience, both worked at Treasury at one point and actually leading different departments within Treasury, including CFIUS.

Of course, we have financial experts, and we have folks that scale technology operations from where we are today to a much larger company. So as of today, we have a majority of independent Board members and we reconstituted all of the committees that's required, of course, to be NASDAQ listed.

We are progressing in terms of removing some of the regulatory -- outstanding regulatory items. So one of them is this FMCSA investigation into an accident last year. 10 million miles, we had 1 liable incident. Again, we should have zero, of course, that's the goal. But having 1 actually is much better than many relative -- I would say, many fleets out there, by most fleets out there. And we learned a lot from this incident. And the results of the incident, our investigation was there was no penalty. And I think it was actually a good working relationship with the FMCSA and we shared a lot more about it on our website.

Now this is a meaty slide, but we -- everyone talks about commercialization, commercial launch. But what does it really mean, right? How do you -- how do I prove to you that we have a path at getting there? And I think, first of all, we'd start from 2 things. One is what is that the consumer wants? And the second is what have you done in the past to show how we can, in the next year or 2, get there? And starting with what consumers want, what the shipper wants is very simple in this industry. It's level of service, so you have to be -- you have to have reliable freight capacity, right? And two, is you have to have on cost -- sorry, on-time delivery.

And second is this cost per mile. And so from those things, what that means is in very early 2022, we demonstrated driver operations, right? That was a demonstration, a validation of our technology, feature complete, the redundancy required. But that wasn't commercialization because we only were running once a week. We were running on nighttime. We had a safety case that encompasses that particular set of operational design domain. And we really didn't care too much about cost, right? There was nonscalable operations in terms of having a survey vehicle, a chase vehicle and, of course, just a pre-trip/post-trip.

And these are all now things we really factor into because the point was to demonstrate that this technology is here, and it's a matter of engineering work to get to next level. Now going from there, as the starting point, there's 3 buckets that we have to work on. One, we had to expand the safety case. So expanded safety case to cover a more larger operational design domain, and that's something we're working on today. We are actively doing third-party auditing for our entire system. And I think that's important for public acceptance.

The second is you have to increase reliability. So reliability means what the shippers care about. You can't have one run per week. It's going to be multiple runs per week, multiple runs per day, day and night, and that's something that -- there are a few things we have to check off or to -- not develop, but to continue to engineer and we're in the progress of doing those.

And lastly is cost effective. And so the way I think about it is with this truck, the truck is a tool and the truck, you can always trade off safety -- efficiency for safety. So if -- what that means is if one, first of all, make sure that we're not hitting anybody, right? So safety aside, everything else becomes cost. And there's sort of nonscalable cost items like a chase vehicle. So that's moving towards our cloud platform of monitoring multiple self-driving trucks. And then one of the other things is the number of the frequency of the truck getting to some sort of degradation mode where we have to trigger a minimum risk condition. A minimum risk condition is where the truck safely pulls over the side of the road, right? This is -- as you can do this safely, then it becomes a cost game.

I mean you can't have MRC every run you do because it probably takes a few hundred dollars to rescue the truck and obviously, it's pain in the butt, too. And so everything else is cost, and that's where a lot of the engineering work is going to today as well. So from Driver Out pilot to initial launch of commercial freight, we want to show that our vehicle is reliable enough to meet the basic demands of a customer, and there's a clear line of sight to be cost-effective on a per cost and per mile basis.

And so our timeline is we're -- sometime in 2024, we believe we can automate one freight lane. And we're automating one freight lane. One of the things we have done is proactively looked at our cost structure, reduce costs, streamline operations, and -- while still hitting the big milestones that's important for shareholders and to our business. And so one of the things we proactively done is to scale back our operations. We're starting with automating one freight lane from Tucson to Phoenix, where we did our Driver Out operations and then scaling from there.

I think it's more cost effective. Our center of operations is there. We're not recreating the entire infrastructure in Texas today, which is very expensive. And -- but it allows us to achieve the same things in terms of going to commercial launch. And one of the exciting things is as we're seeing some movement in California -- actually, if you can automate Tucson to Phoenix and if California opens up, then Port of Long Beach to Phoenix and then down Tucson becomes actually a very, very lucrative freight lane.

So I know we're probably spending a lot more time on the presentation, but one of the cool things that we haven't advertised at all, but -- except for one announcement last year, is we -- in partnership with NVIDIA, we developed our own proprietary supercomputer effectively. Think of this as a centralized compute that is ground-up development. So we license -- we spent a lot of money licensing NVIDIA's SoC. And so everything that goes on to this motherboard in terms of the SoC, other chips, the middleware, sensor support, all these things have been ground-up development.

And the domain controller, typically is called, we call, TuSimple Domain Controller, TDC, is it solves 2 problems. One problem is to actually have a self-driving truck go into production. On the market today, there isn't a computer that's auto grade like that is -- that can support actually the computational needs that we have and for many other self-driving companies. And so today, we're using big mainframes effectively, they're ruggedized, but that could scale to a certain degree, but it's not production ready. So this is.

The second is it actually opens up a lot of near-term monetization opportunities because -- this is the whole industry trend, I think folks that are kind of looking at automotive space as well is really now -- historically, a truck or a vehicle has about a few hundred ECUs, right? And if you look at sensor providers, too, LiDARs, radars, every sensor provider is trying to upsell you with their own software. They're trying to do the -- the raw data, convert that, give you a signal at the sensor level, so there's a chip at a sensor level, and trying to charge OEMs more for it.

The challenge is as you get into really advanced Level 3 -- Level 2+, Level 3 and for self-driving, full self-driving that's not enough. You have to have a central compute that can process many sensor modalities. And it's got to be a low power consumption. And ultimately, low enough cost because for pass car and for trucks, TCO is an important thing. So one of the benefits -- well, the big benefit here is that it does have a distinct competitive advantage for TuSimple building own. And you can argue that the people that's sort of more suitable to develop this piece of hardware are the ones that know how to use the software, right? Because we can actually give the right requirements on how this domain controller is designed.

So that's always been a challenge today. I mean some of the large Tier 1s are developing a domain controller, but again, where does the requirements come from, right? If you want to satisfy many, many people, then this piece of hardware looks a little bit different. It might not satisfy all the -- everyone's needs. So it's actually a very complex piece of hardware. We have about 100 people on the hardware side working on this for the last 1.5 years. We have a very good contract manufacturer based in Asia that is contract manufacturing. We are working with C samples very soon and production will be in the first half of 2024.

And I know -- I mean our core mission is Level 4. We've always stated that. That, of course, is the, call it, the holy grail, right? But we're leveraging a lot of the software development, the technology we learn on Level 4, and we announced last year that starting in China, we're looking at Level 2+ ADAS. And the nice thing about having domain controller, and we actually also make our own cameras, is we're no longer just selling software. You don't make much money selling software. It has to be an integrated solution that the OEMs actually can use.

And so we are actively working with certain OEMs on a Level 2+ solution. So think of this as really next-generation Mobileye. It's -- Mobileye today, it's a camera, radar, plus edge computing. Of course, everyone is moving towards centralized compute plus more sensors. And that's what we are able to offer today. Another kind of cool area is a perception module. So what does that mean? When we talk to a lot of our OEM contact partners, even Tier 1s, we think about self-driving. A lot of these customers want to do their own -- so self-driving a full stack is perception, planning, control. A lot of the OEMs wanted their own planning and control, right? They see that as their secret sauce.

What they don't have the capability of doing is perception, right, which is a lot more deep learning. It's fusing all these different sensor modalities from radars, camera, LiDAR, GPS even and giving them the signal that they need to be able to process their planning and control module. And so think of this as an integrated piece of system with both different sensors plus the domain controller with the application code to give a very precise perception that then can be sold to the OEM for them to do their own planning control. And that's actually -- to be honest, you ask every OEM that's -- deep down, that's what they want to do in this.

And lastly is Level 4 compute. And that is starting off with the TDC can be -- replaces the vehicle control unit. So today, every truck has -- every vehicle has a VCU. And this thing -- with VCU, it's a very, very reliable chip, but it doesn't do too much. It's not a very smart chip. This domain controller replaces the VCU. There's already VCU in the domain controller. And the benefit is if your overall system goes down, this level of redundancy can at least allow the vehicle to cruise for a standard amount of time and to safely pull over, which is very important, as we mentioned before, especially if you're driving on a highway. And the next generation of our TDC can fully replace the central compute and that can go into production trucks.

So the one piece of hardware that we are spending a lot of money actively developing is the one that quite frankly, requires both a very strong understanding of software in order to develop. And that's something that today in the industry has always been a chicken/egg. And so we're proud of this, and we will see more announcements in terms of commercial progress on this domain controller.

And lastly, for better or for worse, when we started the company in 2015, having operations in U.S. and China was seen as a cool thing. It was a good thing, right, you lower cost, resources in China. And of course, the market here in the U.S. is more ready to commercialize. Over time, especially with geopolitical tension, we recognized this. We basically separated 2 businesses. Today, they share a few common public company treasury functions, compliance functions. There are certain things that the China operations effectively is a supplier to the U.S. in terms of certain hardware and data annotation. So we have very cheap data annotation because of our operations in China.

But again, these are really sort of the few touch points we have. And so we do have 2 independent entities. And we have been actively looking at how to unlock value here. You can argue in both sides, you can have multibillion-dollar companies in self-driving. And so how do we unlock value for shareholders, and that's something that we continue to evaluate.

So lastly, in terms of 2023, now we are in the process of bringing on a new auditor. So we will have that hopefully announced soon and be able to release our guidance officially. A few -- 3 buckets -- 4 buckets. One is we are, in terms of capitalization, probably better capitalized than many players out there. We still have very close to $1 billion of cash on hand. With 5% interest rates now, we can actually make some money off the cash. In terms of revenue, we are going to have -- bring down the revenue from last year. And that's because, really, we want to put every dollar to the most -- highest ROI for shareholders and for technology development. It doesn't make sense to have $10 million of revenue while losing $4 million.

We're providing freight capacity at loss before because, one, money was cheap; two, the freight capacity was tight and some of our partners wanted it. And the idea was, ultimately, over time, we'll automate sort of the lanes that we're already in. And we made a conscious decision in December to scale that down and only focus only on the lanes that we want to automate today or this year or next year. So you'll see a decline in revenue, and that's driven by -- that's intentionally driven.

In terms of OpEx, we proactively did a restructuring when I joined back in November. We reduced about 25% of the workforce. The reality is every technology company over the last few years grew too fast, right? And that's going to save at least $60 million on the -- well, $60 million just on the comp for the wages. Of course, besides wages, there's other OpEx that leads to cost savings. And so today, we do have -- we do believe we'll have multiple years of run rate given the cash position that we have. And we'll continue to optimize the OpEx. I mean we have to, as a company in this industry, be smart about this. I mean it's -- we've got to prepare for a longer winter, right? We can assume that the hype for self-driving is going to come back in a year or 2 years, and we have to really march towards getting some product out the door. And so that's how we position our balance sheet. And the CapEx also reflects that mentality.

And lastly, in terms of long-term framework, now we had a setback last year where, I think, in a good position to overcome [many of those things] and we've done a lot over the last few months. We believe we're still the technology leader in self-driving trucks. There's tremendous value, intrinsic value that we bring to the table.

In terms of commercialization, this is with everybody else, we're launching our self-operated fleet first because this is something we don't want to sell to third party, something we can validate ourselves or using retrofitted vehicles today to operate -- no different than robotaxis.

And actually, there's a clear path to basically getting cash flow breakeven with about 500 trucks. I mean 1 truck, 14 hours a day, 50 miles an hour, 300 days a week -- sorry, 300 days a year gets you about $600,000 of revenue. And with 500, that's close to $300 million. And so -- now of course, there's gross margin out there. But there is actually a path to getting to very close to breakeven with 500 trucks. We can do that with a few lanes. We can do that with the technology that we have today now with a little bit more work.

And lastly, when you get to sort of tens of thousands of vehicles, of course, that's where we want to get to, that is something that the OEMs have to produce themselves. It's got to be a factory-produced integrated vehicle at the OEM. The OEM has to validate it, has to provide warranties, manufacturing support. And the reality is, in this case, we're a supplier to OEM, right? We have to enable -- help enable the OEMs and we have to work on the OEM's timeline. And that's something that we have learned the last 2 years working with OEM partners. And that timeline is being pushed back, right? That's not a secret. That's just the industry is being reset and things that were set to be 2024 are now quite closer to 2026. So that's something that I think it's -- that we just had to account for.

So with that, I'll end the presentation part. And hopefully, that gives an overview of some of the initiatives we're working on.

Questions and Answers

BRIAN PATRICK OSSENBECK: Yes. Thanks, Cheng. I feel like we needed that update and there's a lot going on. And I think we'll probably have to come back to those slides afterwards to catch all the details. But that really was comprehensive. Clearly, the industry, the company has undergone several changes. But just to come back to the -- because the focus for a lot of pre-revenue companies now is cash. Clearly, the balance sheet has got $1 billion. You've made some adjustments when you came back on.

But just coming back to the, I guess, the smaller scale with just focusing on the Arizona route. So can that -- it sounds like you can still see a path to breakeven, rather. With the smaller route, you need like a couple of those. You don't need to go to Texas. Like how should we think about the smaller scale with probably a smaller cost structure and then getting to that near-term target?

CHENG LU: Great question. I mean, every day, there's about 20,000 Class A trucks that pass the I-10 -- any given point of the I-10. And so Phoenix to Tucson is a start, I think, with a few routes. I do -- we do have plans to go Texas, but it's important, just like robotaxi, right? You want to get 1 city right first and then move on to the next one. And so that's how we're starting. So if you can have Phoenix to Tucson, if you can get to Long Beach to Phoenix over the next 2 years, even better, and then 1 or 2 routes in Texas, that's more than enough to absorb 500 trucks.

BRIAN PATRICK OSSENBECK: Okay. Got it. So in terms of the -- I think it was out just a little while ago, the FMCSA mentioned the finalized review. Clearly, safety is at the core of this offering and the value proposition. I would agree the nuclear verdicts are not going away anytime soon. But I think the autonomous technology is probably still held to a different standard, at least for the near term. But what were some of the -- you highlighted a few of them, but what were some of the stakeholder reactions after that was all said and done?

It seems like FMCSA was, hopefully, you learned from that process. I'm sure they were appreciative of all the data that you shared. But what are some of the other takeaways from that? And do you think that the industry overall and perception is like, yes, there will be autonomous truck accidents, but there will be a lot fewer than human. Do you think people have really got to that point? Or is it still held to a higher standard like this is a robo driver that should be superhuman?

CHENG LU: Yes. I mean it is still -- it's definitely still held to a higher standard. And unfortunately -- I mean not unfortunately, but that is, I think, human nature. If you look at our safety record, actually, it is better than human-driven -- most human -- most fleets out there. The FMCSA incidents, we -- I think one of the misconceptions is this is something to do with our algorithm, with our core technology. And it's something that we afterwards had improved -- made improvements to our operations. So one of the things, learnings is I think we had to manage the freedom in terms of what the test operator could do.

And so again, that's not the human error. It's our fault, I think, for having -- allowing right, that possibility to be there. Second was there was a -- that particular test run, it was already out of ODD. There were some nodes flashing red, and I think the system still didn't turn on. And so there was a series of sort of events that led to us not catching the fact that there was a hard jerk with a steering wheel. And that's not an algorithm issue. That's a system integration in terms of the latency between kind of the different components in the system.

And so we had to had more gatekeepers in the system and how we kind of -- that's a whole part of functional safety, SOTIF, that's the area of engineering that we'll continue to improve on. And so I think it was a lot of good learnings. And look, these things will -- that's a part of life, right, that there will be incidents, and we have to do our best to, one -- 2 things, make sure that we have a very comprehensive safety case framework. Because usually what happens is when you have an incident, then the regulators say, well -- because regulators don't give you like a box to say, this is how you have to solve everything.

Because when you have an incident, the regulators then come and say, well, did you do the right things? Were you logical enough and look at right things? So then I can't go and say, well, we should have done that. And so that's where having a comprehensive safety case framework, having third-party auditors is important because then we can justify look, we did the right things, right? Like accidents do happen, but we weren't negligent. We didn't do something clearly, obviously, that we should have done. And so I think that's -- a lot of effort has gone into that over the last several years.

BRIAN PATRICK OSSENBECK: So in terms of the industry, we've obviously seen a lot of things change. We've seen one of your competitors, looks like they're going to start to wind down operations. So from your vantage point, is there consolidation that might happen in this space? I know it's mostly people is the key aspect of it, but are there other potentials to see some -- maybe some horizontal mergers?

And then conversely, it seems like from a lot of the updates you're giving here today and you've been working on that you're going a little bit more into -- with the domain controller, with some of these other functions that could actually be a little bit upstream into like a Tier 1 or to an OEM. So it seems like there's maybe -- as with a lot of industries to just start, there's a lot of figuring out what the structure will be. So is your view changed on that at all? And what do you see like in the next couple of years?

CHENG LU: Yes. I mean, I think, certainly, there will be consolidation, there will be companies that don't make it. With any sort of technology company, a lot of new tech -- when I first saw the technology hype curve, I was like, "Oh, that's kind of cute," but actually most tech -- new tech does kind of go through that curve, right? We had the last few years, this inflated expectation of where AV is going to go. That sentiment is coming down.

It's coming back to reality. I think the view is Level 4 is still quite far away and spend a lot of money. So the way we position is, we're marching very fast to Level 4, right? That is our goal. But for the next wave, again, we can't rely on hype. We have to get real products out the door that are meaningful to customers, that can create cash flow. And so the domain controller is something that actually we preplan and it wasn't something we just started this year, it was something we were working on for the last 2 years almost, and that has unlocked more opportunities. So if we can be a next-generation Mobileye plus a real path to Level 4 self-driving, that's something that I think positions us differently, of course, with the balance sheet that we have today.

BRIAN PATRICK OSSENBECK: In terms of a lot of what investors with this long-term path and the big TAM we're trying to figure out the near-term milestones in self-driving. The driverless pilot program was a big one of those. So clearly, there's supply chain issues that are going to make this more challenging and the industry itself is maturing. But what would you say for us to kind of keep a closer eye on? Before, it was, I think, the Union Pacific pilot program, which had a little bit of a delay because of construction, I think.

But -- so the freight world gets in the way sometimes. But what should we focus on in terms of the next steps, the milestones, where I think you guys have been really good at in terms of laying those out there. But of course, with a longer potentially time horizon in different nodes in terms of monetization, there's probably a little bit of a different path we should be considering here.

CHENG LU: Yes. I think there's -- sort of think of it as 2 paths. One is -- the hardest problem in this industry is always sort of defining where the end goal is and where we are relative to that end goal or whatever the goal is. And what I laid out in terms of what does it take to automate 1 freight lane for commercial launch? It's expanding safety, increased reliability, reduction cost. And so from that framework, over the next several quarters, right, we'll give you updates on that. And so at least that shows investors and partners that we are marching towards this systematic framework and we're one step closer every time.

The second path is the domain controller, what that can unlock, and we hope to give more updates in terms of commercial partnerships on that area. So I think these 2 paths, there will be more exciting things to look out for.

BRIAN PATRICK OSSENBECK: And I think you said the domain controller was first half '24, roughly speaking?

CHENG LU: In terms of production. That's right.

BRIAN PATRICK OSSENBECK: Production. Okay. Okay. So maybe just to close out here the last couple of minutes that we have, if you can just give us an update if anything has changed in terms of the partnerships. Level of interest, I would assume, is still pretty high even though the freight market is a little bit softer right now. But clearly, the company has been through a lot of changes. So how is that -- and the Navistar partnership was dissolved. So where do you stand from that perspective?

And then also just because I think we've seen more recent news again on the Board and Xiaodi resigning. It seems like maybe that part is closer to being resolved but not quite all the way there. So maybe you can just -- because I don't think you've covered that part in the presentation, but maybe more recent news. But that would also be helpful just to see when that, I guess, settles down is maybe not the right word, but at least when that becomes less of a focal point.

CHENG LU: Sure. I mean I think all of the issues that happened last year -- look, the reality is it damaged our credibility and reputation. We lost partners, where partners -- sort of the main message was, look, you guys still have the best technology, but get your house in order first, right? I mean as you can expect, especially a lot of partners with big brand names, that's kind of first reaction to have.

So we're actually in the process of rebuilding some of these partnerships. And in a way, we're starting from a very low point. And I think each of these partnerships that we've built hopefully gets us back to where we were before. And with the OEM, with Navistar -- I mean TRATON is still one of our large shareholders. The Navistar relationship in terms of joint development agreement, that was canceled. And we are in discussions with OEMs. And it doesn't impact our near-term launch -- commercial launch, but long term in terms of getting 10,000 trucks, of course, that's something that we have to find a clear path for.

And the one thing in this space is -- which gives me comfort, I guess, ultimately, is that the number of credible, self-driving companies is smaller than number of OEMs out there. And so I do think that this technology obviously is needed and wanted by not only shippers, but also the hardware providers. And so I think I do feel confident that as we work through some of these issues that we'll be able to announce more partnerships there.

In terms of our former CEO, Xiaodi, today, he's no longer part of the company. Starting November, he was only a Board member and not day to day. And so after him resigning from the Board last week, I think that's, again, another sort of thing for us now to move forward. He's obviously a smart guy, but I think in terms of where we need to go next, in terms of really the engineering effort, it's not so much developing algorithms, right? It's more about making the system reliable, functional, going through the (inaudible) and all the stuff.

I think the team today certainly not only has the software and algorithm knowledge but has strong knowledge in terms of getting to a commercial launch. So lots of unfortunate things happened last year, but we are turning the page and in a position to move forward.

BRIAN PATRICK OSSENBECK: Yes. When you came back for a reason, I would assume. So it's good to talk to you again. Good to see again. Clearly, a lot to digest here, but we'll have to end there because we have run out of time. But thank you very much for making time for us today. I appreciate it, Cheng.

CHENG LU: Thanks, Brian. Thanks, everyone.

[77]

India: Two Die, 6 Others Injured Following Communal Clash in Karnataka's Koppal[128]
Some say, Hindus were attacked with swords from Muharram rally.
B Upendran | HENB | Bengaluru | Aug 11, 2022:: As many as two people lost their lives and six others got injured after a clash broke out between two communities viz. Hindus and Muslims in the Hulihyder village of Koppal district in Karnataka. The local administration has imposed Section 144 in the area.
Koppal is a town in Koppal district in the Indian state of Karnataka. Koppal is surrounded on three sides by hills. It is also known as Kopana Nagara. The place is renowned for its historical and religious importance. Koppal is almost 340 km away from Karnataka's capital Bengaluru.
As per a India Today report, on the basis of preliminary information, a Hindu boy was in love with a Muslim girl. During a Muharram program, the boy went to meet the girl, after which arguments broke out between them.
Soon, other people from both communities joined them and started beating each other with bamboo sticks and iron rods. Some sources say that Muslims attacked the Hindus with swords from the Muharram rally.
Over eight people got injured. Two of the injured, Pasha Walli (22) and Yenakapaa Talavad (60) died in the hospital.
A police team reached the site of the incident and took the situation under control. Section 144 has been imposed in the village as a precautionary measure.
The news agency ANI also confirmed the clash in Koppal.
Further investigation into the incident is going on.
[1][77]

Islamic Dominance in India Though Demographic Change[129]
Silent Muslim invasion through demographic change to end the Hindu majority in India.
The Secular analysts and so called demography experts always hint that Muslim population is not any danger for the Hindu majority India anyway.
But, the Census of India (through its religious population census) gives us a clear picture about the high concentration of Muslim population across India area/district/metropolitan-sector wise.
In a consideration of 50% and above as 'Muslim majority', 49%-30% Muslim population as 'Highly Muslim influenced' and 29%-10% Muslim population as 'Muslim influenced' areas/districts/metropolitan-sectors; a huge number of Muslim concentrations are found through the available 2011 Census data of India.
So far, 37 Muslim majority, 33 highly Muslim influenced and 94 Muslim influenced areas/districts/metropolitan-sectors are found in an analysis of Census data. However, the numbers in highly Muslim influenced and Muslim influenced areas may be higher than the estimation as Muslim population growth, infiltration etc. has been moderately high during this period 2011 and 2022 further.
More than are quite few, we have tried to list up the districts where Muslim population is more than or equal to the state overall percentage as below. This has been prepared from the available data of Census 2011[Go through search option for desired data state & category wise]
[1][77]

Jacinda Ardern Blasted as New Zealanders Are Forced to Sleep in Their Cars[130]
Former New Zealand Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters has slammed the NZ government after a shock report revealed the extent of the nation's cost of living crisis.
Latest figures showed that hundreds of New Zealanders were suffering through a freezing Winter living in their cars with those on the ground describing the conditions as 'heart-breaking'.
[77]

Sierra Leone Shuts Off Internet Access to Crush Cost-of-Living Protests[131]
Amid anti-government protests on Wednesday afternoon, the West African country of Sierra Leone experienced an almost total internet blackout. The protests were about the rising cost of living, with some calling for the resignation of the current president.
According to internet governance watchdog NetBlocks, for about two hours starting noon on Wednesday, connectivity fell to about 5% of the normal level. Some fixed-line and mobile internet operators went totally dark.
[77]

At Least 150 Migrants Arrived in the UK Today — With 2,309 Crossing the Channel by Boat in August Alone as Temperatures Soar[132]
At least 150 migrants arrived in Britain by boat today as they took advantage of the good weather to make the perilous journey across the English Channel.
The groups were made up of mostly young men and male teenagers, some of whom put their thumbs up as they appeared visibly relieved while being ferried to shore by Border Force.
Figures released by the Ministry of Defence (MoD) today show the number of migrants to reach UK shores in the past 11 days alone is now 2,309.
[77]

Belgium: Tourist Wearing Luxury Watch Robbed by Illegal Migrants at Brussels Hotel[133]
A tourist was robbed by illegal migrants who ambushed him at his hotel in Brussels and stole his designer watch, according to reports.
The disturbing incident unfolded on Tuesday evening in Belgium's capital city.
A man wearing a Hublot timepiece valued at over $30,000 was returning to his hotel when he was attacked by a male suspect, Bruzz reports.
[77]

DC Mayor Muriel Bowser Asks National Guard Again to Help Deal With Migrants Being Bused From Texas After the Pentagon Refused — and Claims There is Still a 'Humanitarian Crisis'[134]
he mayor of Washington D.C. on Thursday renewed her plea for soldiers to help with migrants being bused to her city, a week after the Pentagon rebuffed her request for the National Guard to be deployed.
It came as another bus from Texas was spotted at dawn, unloading migrants in front of the U.S. Capitol.
In a letter to the secretary of defense, Mayor Muriel Bowser said support was needed to 'help prevent a prolonged humanitarian crisis in our nation's capital.'
[77]

France: Migrant Gangs Engage in Massive Brawl in Paris Suburb[135]
A video depicting a massive brawl between gangs of Egyptian and Algerian nationals in France has garnered hundreds of thousands of views on social media. There are numerous commentators describing the violence as a consequence of French President Emmanuel Macron's immigration policies.
The video, which was published by Reconqute political candidate Ccile Scheffen, shows two massive groups of armed men, some of whom have rebars and spiked bats beating one another as onlookers look upon the scenes in stunned disbelief.
[77]

Germany: Syrian Migrant Stabs Female Worker Multiple Times at Immigration Center[136]
An immigration office in the western German city of Wuppertal was closed on Thursday after an employee was stabbed several times by a 20-year-old Syrian national.
According to the Bild newspaper, the assailant stormed into the 'House of Integration' building shortly before 9 a.m. local time on Thursday, 'jumped over the reception desk in the entrance area, and suddenly stabbed the woman.'
The motive for the seemingly indiscriminate attack is unknown.
[77]

Germany Agrees to Take Even More Migrants in EU Redistribution Scheme[137]
The German government has agreed to take as many as 3,500 migrants from Italy in the first use of a European Union migrant redistribution scheme that was agreed upon last year.
Germany is expected to receive its first asylum seekers from Italy at some point this month and has so far accepted to take in at least 3,500 people, as part of 13 countries agreeing to take in over 8,000 migrants from countries like Italy to reduce the stress on states along the European Union border.
[77]

Hungary Begins Reinforcing Its Southern Border Fence as Migration Pressure Builds[138]
As migrant flows swell and they begin using increasingly aggressive tactics to enter Hungary, the country has responded by reinforcing its fence on its border with Serbia due to increasing migration pressure.
In the last year, more and more migrants on their way to Western Europe ended up stuck in Serbia near the border with Hungary. These groups used various methods to scale or break through Hungary's fence, including violence.
[77]

Migrants Use Charity Cash to Flee NYC When They Can't Get Into Shelter[139]
The city's shelter system is too dysfunctional for these migrants!
Four asylum-seekers who braved trekking to the US-Mexico border — and across it — got so fed up waiting for beds in New York City that they used charity money to get out and head to Washington, DC, The Post has learned.
[77]

Smiling Migrants Take Selfies as They Cross the Med in Packed Wooden Boat — Only for Their Vessel to Sink Moments Later Sparking Rescue Operation Off Italian Island[140]
With mobile phone in hand, a migrant leans back on a packed wooden boat as he takes a selfie during his crossing to Europe.
But scenes of joy quickly turned to disaster off the southern Italian island of Lampedusa this morning when the overloaded vessel capsized leaving dozens stranded in the choppy waters.
Chaotic images show some 40 migrants from Eritrea and Sudan fighting to stay afloat after they tumbled overboard when the strained vessel started taking on water.
[77]

UK: It Wasn't an Accident[141]
New stats released in the UK show nearly 1 of every 3 babies is born to a foreign mother.
None of this was accidental.
[77]

Britain's Tavistock Gender Clinic to Face Legal Action From 1,000 Families[142]
The Tavistock Gender Clinic in the United Kingdom, which has been ordered to close by early next year, is facing legal action from around 1,000 families whose children were railroaded into undergoing gender reassignment procedures.
The procedures, which typically involve the use of permanently body-altering puberty blockers, as well as hormone replacement therapy, were prescribed to children who went to the Tavistock clinic for consultation over potentially having gender dysphoria.
As detailed by Rebel News, a lengthy government review found that children referred to the gender clinic were given rushed diagnoses and prescribed gender transitions with no regard to other preexisting mental health issues.
[77]

Counselor for Sex Offenders Defends 'Minor-Attracted Persons'[143]
A counselor for sex offenders who works with the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections has stoked controversy after defending 'minor attracted persons' and comparing pedophilia to a normal sexual preference.
In a video posted to YouTube that has since been clipped and posted to Twitter, Miranda Galbreath describes adults who are sexually attracted to children as 'probably the most vilified population of folks in our culture.'
'The term pedophile has moved from being a diagnostic label to being a judgmental, hurtful insult that we hurl at people in order to harm them or slander them,' Galbreath insisted.
[77]

Elite Nashville Girls School Welcomes Any Student Who Identifies as Female[144]
Harpeth Hall, an elite school for girls in grades 5-12 in Nashville, Tenn., announced that 'any student who identifies as a girl' is welcome to apply.
The school, which was founded in 1865, includes alumnae such as actress Reese Witherspoon, comedienne Minnie Pearl and Christian singer Amy Grant. Tuition for this upcoming school year is more than $32,000.
In a handout titled 'Gender Diversity Philosophy at Harpeth Hall,' the school states: 'As the world evolves, so do our students. The concept of gender has expanded and deepened over time.'
[77]

How Gender Ideology Cost a Chicago Mother Custody of Her Child[145]
Jeannette Cooper never imagined she'd lose custody of her only child.
A Chicago resident and lifelong educator who spent her entire adult life surrounded by children, Cooper considered herself a loving and responsible mother. After she and her husband divorced in 2015, she won custody of their daughter six days and seven nights a week.
Cooper says the two shared a happy, healthy mother-daughter relationship, bonding over their love for board games and progressive politics.
But on July 22, 2019, after a regular custodial visit to her father's house, Cooper's daughter, then 12, refused to come home. The next morning, she insisted not only that she was transgender, but that she felt 'unsafe' around her mom.
[77]

Sesame Place Cancels Latina Character After Black Family Sued Over 'Racism'[146]
Sesame Place has reportedly canceled Rosita, the bilingual Muppet character from Mexico by removing her from the daily parade as well as meet and greets after a black family sued the amusement park for $25 million.
[77]

Telegram Says Apple is Blocking a 'Revolutionary' Update[147]
Apple has delayed what it calls a 'revolutionary' Telegram update for two weeks without explanation, according to Telegram's founder Pavel Durov. He added that this is another example of the 'unfair practices' of tech giants faced by developers.
'The only thing we find frustrating is that we often fail to release new versions of Telegram due to convoluted mobile app reviews by tech monopolists. For example, our latest update that will revolutionize how people express themselves through messages, got stuck for two weeks at Apple's verification without any explanation of the reasons and comments from Apple,' Durov wrote in his Telegram channel.
[77]

Trudeau Government Blacklists Alexander Graham Bell for 'Controversial Beliefs'[148]
Alexander Graham Bell is next on the woke historical revisionist chopping block.
A federal government body is investigating posthumous honours received by the Canadian inventor of the telephone due to his 'controversial beliefs.'
According to Blacklock's Reporter, the Historic Sites and Monuments Board stated that it was reviewing the designations because of 'views, actions and activities condemned by today's society.'
Board members did not provide any details about what supposed controversial beliefs Bell held when flagging him for the review.
[77]

Vancouver Hiring Lifeguards Committed to 'Decolonization and Equity'[149]
A City of Vancouver job posting for a lifeguard position requires applicants to be committed to the woke ideals of 'decolonization and equity.'
'The Vancouver Board of Parks and Recreation is inviting applications from interested and qualified candidates for the summer intake of Lifeguard I employees for various outdoor pools and beaches in Vancouver,' the ad states.
'the City of Vancouver seeks colleagues who can help shape and embody our core commitments to sustainability, decolonization, equity and outstanding quality of life for all residents.'
[77]

WEF Wants to Use AI to Automate Censorship of 'Disinformation'[150]
The World Economic Forum (WEF) has revealed its latest scheme: they want to use AI to automate the censorship of whatever they deem 'hate speech' and 'disinformation.'
According to an article published by WEF, there is an urgent need to utilize 'human-curated, multi-language, off-platform intelligence into learning sets' so that AI can detect online abuse before it ever reaches mainstream platforms.
The Forum says this is necessary to stop the proliferation of everything from child abuse to extremism, disinformation, hate speech, and fraud.
[77]

U.S. Attorney's Office

Western District of Washington

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

Member of timber poaching group that set Olympic National Forest wildfire sentenced to 2 1/2 years in prison

Defendant was a member of the poaching group that started the 2018 Maple Fire

Tacoma - One of two men charged in a scheme to steal maple wood that resulted in a massive 2018 forest fire on the Olympic Peninsula was sentenced to prison today in U.S. District Court in Tacoma, announced U.S. Attorney Brian T. Moran. SHAWN EDWARD WILLIAMS, 49, was sentenced to 30 months in prison and three years of supervised release for theft of public property and setting timber afire. At the sentencing hearing, U.S. District Judge Benjamin H. Settle said that "the consequences of your actions . . . resulted in horrendous consequences to the forests."

According to records filed in the case, between April and August 2018, lead defendant Justin Andrew Wilke conducted an illegal logging operation in the Elk Lake area of the Olympic National Forest, near Hood Canal. In July 2018, just days after his release from state prison, WILLIAMS joined the conspiracy, helping Wilke remove maple from the National Forest and transporting it with Wilke to a mill in Tumwater, Washington. The type of maple harvested by the defendants is highly prized and used to produce musical instruments.

On August 3, 2018, the group decided to cut a maple tree that contained a wasp's nest near the base of the tree. To remove the nest, the group sprayed insecticide and gasoline on the nest and base of the tree and then lit the nest on fire. The group failed to extinguish the fire, which developed into a wildfire later named the "Maple Fire." The Maple Fire consumed more than 3,300 acres between August and November 2018 and cost approximately $4.2 million to contain. WILLIAMS did not himself set the fire, but was present when others set the fire.

WILLIAMS pleaded guilty in December 2019.

In their sentencing memo, prosecutors highlighted the danger of Wilke and WILLIAMS's conduct. "Forest fires present a dire and growing threat in this region. They destroy our forests, poison our air, and endanger responders, local residents, recreationalists, and wildlife. When this fire occurred in early August 2018, the Puget Sound region was (as it is today) already experiencing significant smoke from existing wildfires, and the high risk of fire was evident to everyone in Western Washington. Despite this atmosphere, Williams participated in taking the extreme risk of setting fire to a portion of a tree-deep in the forest, in mid-summer. The consequences of that decision-thousands of acres burned, millions of dollars in containment costs, and the release of huge amounts of smoke-were easily foreseeable."

The case was investigated by the United States Forest Service. The case is being prosecuted by Assistant United States Attorneys Seth Wilkinson and Will Dreher.

Contact:

Press contact for the U.S. Attorney's Office is Communications Director Emily Langlie at (206) 553-4110 or Emily.Langlie@usdoj.gov

Updated September 21, 2020

Renee Miller: at the crossroads of neuroscience and fantasy sports Climate change is burning up the U.S. The unwelcome pardon2020-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:56ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Welcome to the new campustimes.org. Renee Miller: at the crossroads of neuroscience and fantasy sports Climate change is burning up the U.S. The unwelcome pardonSarah Woodams

It's the end of the West Coast as we know it, and I feel fine. 

This is one of those moments where I am extremely grateful that I live in Rochester, where the worst weather is measured in feet of snow rather than acres of fire. Other Americans aren't so lucky.

People in California, Oregon, and Washington are living in some twisted version of the "This is fine" meme. Their red and orange skies are filling with ash as President Trump blames poor forest management, rather than climate change, for these deadly wildfires. In 2020 alone, wildfires have burned over 6 million acres of land in the U.S. Thousands of firefighters, over a thousand of which are inmates, are currently battling over 100 large fires out west. So far, at least 35 people have died and dozens have been declared missing.

When told that the White House needs to listen to science to protect against future wildfires, Trump responded, "I don't think science knows." Maybe he didn't understand that the "science is a liar sometimes" bit from "It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia" was a joke. 

Or maybe his campaign is funded by fossil fuel leaders and lobbyists who profit off of his anti-science stance. We'll just never know.

While humans start over 90% of forest fires (Smokey the Bear really needs to work on increasing his audience), climate change provides prime conditions for these fires to grow and spread. These factors include fuel availability (sticks, brush, fallen trees, etc.), fuel moisture content (preferably dry), wind (the faster it is, the more the fire will spread), and lightning strikes.

Researchers found that among larger class fires (between sizes of 300 and 5,000 acres), there was a strong negative correlation between fire activity and pre-fire season soil moisture content. Basically, the drier the soil, the more likely there will be fires during fire season.

Dr. Philip Duffy, President and Executive Director of the Woodwell Climate Research Center, stresses that the planet is undoubtedly warming every year. Among other environmental crises, it's clear that this temperature increase has intensified forest fires. 

Duffy says the hot, dry weather that results from climate change creates "fuel conditions" (mainly dried-out forests) that are "conducive to fire." These conditions help fires spread their destruction as far as possible.

Good forest management can reduce risk, Duffy says, but he emphasizes that the best solution is to stop releasing so many greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.

We can't ignore science if we want to limit the number of environmental crises we experience every year. Our perilous situation will only get worse, not just in the forest fire-prone western U.S., but around the entire world. Trump's inaction and lies about climate change and science are killing Americans and will harm the rest of the world if we continue down this path. 

Yes, climate change is real. Yes, it's making fires worse. And no, we cannot wait to take action.

urn:contentItem:60H6-0B51-DY68-14F9-00000-00'Inuyasha' Sequel Clip Appears Online, More Information Coming Soon2020-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:56ZLexisNexis'Inuyasha' Sequel Clip Appears Online, More Information Coming SoonPhillip Martinez

Fans can expect more information on this series on August 7.

Ahead of the anime's release, the first clip of Yashahime: Princess Half-Demon--the sequel to the popular Inuyasha series--was appeared online.

The promotional video was aired in Japan, captured and shared online via Twitter by user @RanobeSugoi. The clip is without voice lines or sound effects, but does show the character designs in full color and some of the mannerisms and quirks of the main three characters.

Take a look at the first clip of Yasahime: Princess Half-Demon below.

Not much is shown during this first clip of the Inuyasha sequel anime, but fans get to see some of the personalities of the main cast.

Moroha, the daughter of Inuyasha and Kagome, is seen as a rambunctious, over-confident fighter similar to her father. The official site describes Moroha as "cheerful" and while she has a lot of her parents' traits she doesn't know it, as she grew up without them.

Towa is the twin of Setsuna and the daughter of Sesshomaru. From the clip, she seems much more level-headed and book smart. She was separated from her sister and have now reunited, but Setsuna has no memory of Towa.

Setsuna, on the other hand, is stoic and looks dangerous similar to her father. She wields a bladed staff and makes a living by destroying demons.

The official Yashime: Princes Half-DemonTwitter account revealed over the weekend that new information about the story and anime will arrive on August 7. Perhaps fans will get a proper release of an extended clip of the upcoming anime. Fans will just have to wait and see.

Here's the full synopsis for Yashime: Princess Half-Demon:

In Feudal Japan, Half-Demon twins Towa and Setsuna are separated from each other during a forest fire. While desperately searching for her younger sister, Towa wanders into a mysterious tunnel that sends her into present-day Japan, where she is found and raised by Kagome Higurashi's brother, Sota, and his family.

Ten years later, the tunnel that connects the two eras has reopened, allowing Towa to be reunited with Setsuna, who is now a Demon Slayer working for Kohaku. But to Towa's shock, Setsuna appears to have lost all memories of her older sister.

Joined by Moroha, the daughter of Inuyasha and Kagome, the three young women travel between the two eras on an adventure to regain their missing past.

Back in May, the sequel series was announced for a fall release in Japan. Viz Media will distribute the series in North America, but no date for a possible English-language release has been announced.

The Inuyasha sequel is being developed by Japanese production company Sunrise, which had a hand in the original Inuyasha anime.

What do you think of the first clip from the Inuyasha sequel? Let us know in the comments section.

urn:contentItem:650Y-GN11-F03R-N36X-00000-00Climate-driven Water Woes Spark Colorado Rush To Conserve 'Liquid Gold'2022-03-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:56ZLexisNexisClimate-driven Water Woes Spark Colorado Rush To Conserve 'Liquid Gold'

Mar 16, 2022( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)
In a rooftop greenhouse near downtown Denver, cash crops are thriving on hydroponic life support. Arugula. Chard. Escarole. Cabbage.
"And basil," said Altius Farms CEO Sally Herbert, plucking a bright leaf. "Which you really should taste. Because it's magnificent."


The vertical farm is one of many Colorado models for coping with increasing water scarcity in the western United States, as climate change makes droughts more frequent and more severe.
Other projects have Coloradans testing water recycling and building barriers against the wildfire runoff that can taint supplies.
Colorado is hardly alone. A major U.N. climate report published recently notes that half the world's population is already seeing severe water scarcity for at least some part of the year. In the U.S. West, drought and earlier runoff from an increasingly diminished snowpack will increase water scarcity during the summer, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change said.
While Colorado so far has met the water needs of its 6 million residents, it could face a roughly 30% shortfall by 2050 as the population grows while climate impacts escalate, according to one likely scenario experts prepared for the state's official Water Plan https://cwcb.colorado.gov/colorado-water-plan/technical-update-to-the-plan.
Already, the region's worst drought in more than a century has left water levels starkly low in the Lake Mead reservoir supplying Colorado River water to neighboring states.
"It's mind-blowing," Herbert said.
FARMING UPWARD
No one fix will ensure future water quality, quantity and affordability. Approaches such as water recycling have faced regulatory gaps and public resistance.
Vertical farming, meanwhile, won't work at the scale needed for staple crops like corn or wheat. And while Altius uses mostly natural light to grow 25,000 pounds (11,300 kg) of produce each year on its 7,000-square-foot rooftop, others rely on lamps and electricity. That can make the produce grown pricier.
Still, vertical farms use 95% less water than traditional farming. Other benefits can include reduced transportation costs, with produce grown closer to where consumers live. And foods that can be grown indoors can be a boon outside of temperate regions, said Michael Dent, an agriculture and food technology analyst at the IDTechEx market research group.
Such benefits are luring investment: Georgia-based multinational Kalera is now repurposing a warehouse near Denver's airport - close to highways and supermarket distribution centers. The company, founded in 2010, grows produce in the Middle East, Asia and Europe, with plans to expand further.
Retail giant Walmart Inc in January joined a $400 million funding round by the San Francisco vertical startup Plenty, a deal still subject to regulatory approval.
And last year, New York-based vertical startup Bowery Farming raised $300 million in a funding round.
It can be tough to assess a vertical farm's overall environmental footprint. A farm run on wind power will have fewer polluting carbon emissions than one run on fossil fuels, for example.
Kalera Chief Commercial Officer Henner Schwarz said there's "frankly speaking, a lot of smoke and mirrors. Everybody has the 'most sustainable technology' and lots of blah, blah."
"But when it comes to water savings, I'm actually very confident in saying that we use only 3% of the water traditional agriculture would use," Schwarz said.
'LIQUID GOLD'
At a home construction site, a plumbing crew huddled around a black, refrigerator-size piece of technology.
Once hooked up, the system would siphon off and filter shower and bath water, removing skin cells, soap and hair before sending the water back to the toilets for flushing. "This is the first one that has taken the filtration to this level," said Todd Moritzky, the plumbing company's owner.
His crew were working on a house construction by Lennar in Castle Rock, south of Denver. Lennar said using the filtration system, made by the Canadian company Greyter, in earlier builds had cut home water use by up to 25%.
"Water is liquid gold here," said Eric Feder, Lennar's Colorado-based director of national efforts to embrace homebuilding innovations. The company would like to make Greyter systems the standard in its homes, he said.
But in Colorado, Castle Rock along with Denver and Pitkin County are the only three communities that allow in-home water recycling.
"Plumbing codes, ordinances, local regulations are just catching up to that technology availability," said Pat Sinicropi, head of the WateReuse trade association.
Castle Rock gets less than 15 inches (38 cm) of precipitation a year. The town, with a population of 70,000, is projected to grow to 100,000 by 2060. It is aiming to reduce its daily water consumption from about 115 gallons per person to below 100 gallons within a decade.
"We fully intend to achieve it," said Mark Marlowe, director of Castle Rock Water. The utility now offers home developers fee discounts if they install systems such as Greyter's.
SAFE TO DRINK
Just south of Castle Rock in Colorado Springs, Tzahi Cath has been working with the local utility to demonstrate that recycled wastewater can be used not just to flush toilets, but also for drinking.
The Colorado School of Mines engineering professor and his students in Golden built a portable water treatment laboratory to further process the utility's partly treated wastewater so that its safe for consumption.
The idea isn't new. Singapore has been treating sewage and recycling the water back into its reservoirs since 2003. San Diego, California, is building sewage recycling infrastructure. And Cath's desert homeland of Israel is a world leader in desalinating seawater for drinking and treating wastewater for irrigation use.
Cath produced a half-million gallons of potable water from June through December - serving nearly 1,000 people who visited his lab. Most of those taste testers deemed the water good.
"The state needs to start investing and utilities need to start building the infrastructure" to allow utilities to clean and deliver reclaimed waste water for drinking, Cath said.
State officials are urging citizens to conserve water, while they also look to boost funding for infrastructure.
The state needs at least 10 times the $25 million currently allotted in its annual budget for the Department of Natural Resources, which funds water projects, according to the state's official Water Plan.
FIRE TAINT
Apart from concerns about having enough water, Colorado is facing an increasing threat of wildfires sullying the supplies it does have.
Last summer, the college town of Fort Collins had to let some Cache la Poudre River water flow away after it was contaminated with ash and debris from a forest fire the year before.
Wildfires wipe out vegetation that would normally soak up some rainwater, leading to erosion and contaminated runoff for years. A study published in this month's journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences warned of an increase in hazards such as flooding and landslides in burned out areas of the U.S. West.
Fort Collins also has a water reservoir, so losing some from the Poudre supply wasn't an immediate crisis.
Workers have been building permanent structures, at a cost of some $300,000, to block fire debris from getting into the water treatment plant, said Mark Kempton, interim deputy director for utilities at Fort Collins Water Resources & Treatment.
In the future, Kempton said, we could see "fire response becoming part of regular water rate increases."

urn:contentItem:62SN-SXD1-DYVF-91S3-00000-00Film caps 5-28-212021-05-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:56ZLexisNexisTODOPg. 2Film caps 5-28-21

Here's a list of movies now playing in Cheyenne. Local theaters are noted at the end of each capsule. Summaries provided by the Los Angeles Times and IMDB.

Note: Frontier 9 is still closed.

"A Quiet Place Part II" (PG-13) Following the events at home, the Abbott family now face the terrors of the outside world. Forced to venture into the unknown, they realize the creatures that hunt by sound are not the only threats lurking beyond the sand path. With Emily Blunt, Millicent Simmonds, Cillian Murphy. Written by John Krasinski, Scott Beck and Bryan Woods. Directed by John Krasinski. (1:37) Capitol 12

"Cruella" (PG-13) This A live-action prequel feature film follows a young Cruella de Vil. With Emma Stone, Emma Thompson, Joel Fry. Written by Dana Fox, Tony McNamara, Aline Brosh McKenna, Kelly Marcel and Steve Zissis based on the novel "One Hundred and One Dalmatians" by Dodie Smith. Directed by Craig Gillespie. (2:14) Capitol 12

"Dream Horse" (PG) Dream Alliance is an unlikely race horse bred by small-town Welsh bartender Jan Vokes. With no experience, Jan convinces her neighbors to chip in their meager earnings to help raise Dream in the hopes he can compete with the racing elites. With Toni Collette, Damian Lewis, Siân Phillips. Written by Neil McKay. Directed by Euros Lyn. (1:53) Capitol 12

"The Dry" (R) Aaron Falk returns to his drought-stricken hometown to attend a tragic funeral. But his return opens a decades-old wound - the unsolved death of a teenage girl. With Eric Bana, Genevieve O'Reilly, Keir O'Donnell. Written by Harry Cripps, Robert Connolly, Jane Harper and Samantha Strauss. Directed by Robert Connolly. (1:57) Capitol 12

"Finding You" (PG) Finley, a talented aspiring violinist, meets Beckett, a famous young movie star, on the way to her college semester abroad program in Ireland. An unexpected romance emerges as heartthrob Beckett leads uptight Finley on an adventurous reawakening. With Katherine McNamara, Jedidiah Goodacre, Vanessa Redgrave. Written and directed by Brian Baugh. (1:55) Capitol 12

"Grease" (PG-13) Good girl Sandy Olsson and greaser Danny Zuko fell in love over the summer. When they unexpectedly discover they're now in the same high school, will they be able to rekindle their romance? With John Travolta, Olivia Newton-John, Stockard Channing. Written by Bronte Woodard and Allan Carr based on the musical by Jim Jacobs and Warren Casey. (1:50) Capitol 12

"Mortal Kombat" (R) MMA fighter Cole Young seeks out Earth's greatest champions in order to stand against the enemies of Outworld in a high stakes battle for the universe. With Lewis Tan, Jessica McNamee, Josh Lawson. Written by Greg Russo, Dave Callaham, Oren Uziel and Greg Russo based on the video game created by Ed Boon and John Tobias. Directed by Simon McQuoid. (1:50) Capitol 12

"Raya and the Last Dragon" (PG) In a realm known as Kumandra, a re-imagined Earth inhabited by an ancient civilization, a warrior named Raya is determined to find the last dragon. With Kelly Marie Tran, Awkwafina, Gemma Chan. Written by Qui Nguyen and Adele Lim, Paul Briggs, Don Hall, Adele Lim, Carlos López Estrada, Kiel Murray, Qui Nguyen, John Ripa and Dean Wellins. (1:54) Capitol 12

"Spiral" (R) A criminal mastermind unleashes a twisted form of justice in Spiral, the terrifying new chapter from the book of Saw. With Chris Rock, Samuel L. Jackson, Morgan David Jones. Written by Josh Stolberg and Pete Goldfinger. Directed by Darren Lynn Bousman. (1:33) Capitol 12

"Those Who Wish Me Dead" (R) A teenage murder witness finds himself pursued by twin assassins in the Montana wilderness with a survival expert tasked with protecting him - and a forest fire threatening to consume them all. With Angelina Jolie, Nicholas Hoult, Finn Little. Written by Michael Koryta, Charles Leavitt and Taylor Sheridan based on the book by Michael Koryta. Directed by Taylor Sheridan. (1:40) Capitol 12

"Wrath of Man" (R) The plot follows H, a cold and mysterious character working at a cash truck company responsible for moving hundreds of millions of dollars around Los Angeles each week. With Jason Statham, Holt McCallany, Josh Hartnett. Written by Nicolas Boukhrief, Éric Besnard, Guy Ritchie, Marn Davies and Ivan Atkinson. Directed by Guy Ritchie. (1:58) Capitol 12

urn:contentItem:5YRD-TF51-JB72-14JK-00000-00Fire And Police Departments Taking Extra Measures To Prevent Spread Of COVID-19 With Local Company's Donation Of Professional Disinfection Application Services2020-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:15:56ZLexisNexisFire And Police Departments Taking Extra Measures To Prevent Spread Of COVID-19 With Local Company's Donation Of Professional Disinfection Application ServicesChicago Water & Fire Restoration Offers Free EPA-Approved COVID-19 Cleaning and Decontamination Services to Fire and Police DepartmentsCHICAGO, April 23, 2020

PR Newswire

 Chicago Water & Fire Restorationis donating disinfection application services to local fire and police departments as a preventative response measure to the rising threat of the COVID-19 Coronavirus. The Arlington Heights Fire Department, Village of Lincolnwood's fire and police departments, Yorkville Police Department, Lake Forest Fire Department, among others have completed the donated services. The free services are also available to other interested departments.

The company follows CDC cleaning guidelines and the application of EPA-registered products to guard against bacteria and viruses. The staff is fully trained and certified and uses PPE equipment to minimize exposure during all visits. Teams are available 24/7 and can be dispatched as soon as needed.

"It feels great to be able to give back to the community, especially in such a difficult time.  We felt it was important to take the initiative to keep our first responders safe," says John Montalbano, general manager ofChicago Water & Fire Restoration. "It's been a morale boost for our company and allowed us to focus on what we can do to help, rather than stand by helpless."

Disinfection application services include cleaning and decontamination of:

Restroom doors, handrails, toilets, partitions, soap dispensers Electronics such as phones, computers, keyboards, mice, tablets Floors, doors, doorknobs, walls, light switches Kitchen countertops, dining surfaces, appliance handles, cabinet knobs, chairs Public areas such as elevators buttons, water fountains, door handles and other high touch areas

Although there is no guarantee of eliminatingCOVID-19, this process defined by the CDC and EPA can help reduce contamination.  Fire and police stations can schedule free services athttp://www.cwafr.com/fd or reach out for more sanitizing services by emailingdisinfect@cwafr.com

ABOUT CHICAGO WATER & FIRE RESTORATIONAs a full-service restoration company,Chicago Water & Fire Restorationoffers on-site estimates 24/7 with a 60-90 minute response and a full Lifetime Guarantee on materials and workmanship. Serving all of Chicago and surrounding counties, the company promises a live person will field calls 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The response team is I.I.C.R.C. certified and ready to accommodate emergency needs. For more information, please visithttps://chicagowaterandfire.com/.

MEDIA CONTACT:Paramount Public Relations
Jessica Prah, 312-953-3257,jessica@paramountpr.com
